_prev_prog_2.CH_OtherChanges: Helena updated the RMP to require Independent Contractors to provide PSM, hazard review procedures, and updates.
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Helena personnel conduct routine inspections on its tanks and ancillary equipment.  Inspection of all blending, ancillary, and transport vessels is performed by the responsible Independent Contractor.
_prev_prog_2.Description: The Depot Manager implements the RMP at this facility and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. The RMP includes multiple attachments which address its prevention program. The ammonia handling process is implemented by an independent contractor. To ensure that the independent contractor is responsible for complying with relevant operation, maintenance, training and contingency procedures, Helena requires that the independent contractor certify that it: (1) operates under an OSHA PSM, and (2) complies with Helena's shut-down and notification procedures. Furthermore, Helena requires for its independent contractor to prepare and make available its hazard review, and operating and maintenance procedures relevant to the blending process.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Helena Chemical Company (Helena) Brunswick Facility has submitted this updated electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act 112 (r) as codified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency at 40 CFR Part 68. Standards codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration at 29 CFR 1910.119 are not applicable to the operations at this facility because the facility is operated as a retail operation and is exempt from the OSHA standards. This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from the Brunswick Facility located at 5234 Highway 20, Brunswick, NE 68720.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Brunswick Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Brunswick Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release (even though a release is unlikely) will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.

PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP

Helena has updated this RMP in response to recent changes in its management of the RMP program.  As part of the update, Helena updated the off-site consequence analysis for the worst case scenario and alternative case scenario because the original RMP did not accurately reflect the use of an Independent Contractor to conduct the on-site blending/reacting operations. This updated RMP reflects an increase in the chemical inventory. 

FACILITY

The Brunswick Facility is a retail agricultural chemical facility.  Anhydrous ammonia is unloaded from a railcar and batch processed through a reactor.  The process operations conducted at this facility are performed by an independent contractor.  The independent contractor performs the batch reactor operations using a mobile pipe reactor.  The batch operations consist of unloading the anhydrous ammonia from the rail car into the reactor and mixing it with water and p

hosphoric acid to produce ammonium phosphate fertilizer.  The contractor is responsible to OSHA for Process Safety Management compliance. Helena Chemical Company does not own or operate the formulation processes at the facility. 
 
OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst case and alternative consequence analysis were completed for the ammonia storage process. The worst case scenario release for the Brunswick Facility assumed that all the contents in the largest single storage tank were released.  The release was modeled as if the ammonia tank was punctured on the side at the ground level. The resulting release of ammonia was modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.

The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario assumes a rupture of a 3-inch line caused by an impact from a vehicle or some other source on the liquid ammonia transfer line during a major loading or unloading operation.  Although this event is classified as an alternative scenario, even an accident of this type is unlikely to occur due to the safety equipment (rail guards, check valves) and operating procedures that Helena requires for its Independent Contractors to uses during ammonia transfer operations.

Both the worst case and alternative scenario are overly conservative because even a 2-minute release is unlikely to occur since check valves on the system should close immediately upon increased flow resulting from the severed transfer line.

ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Depot Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Helena facility.  The Depot Manager is assisted by other Helena staff, as directed.  The fertilizer handling process is implemented by an Independent Contractor.  

To ensure that its contractor is responsible to Helena for complying with relevant operation, maintenance, training procedures and documentation, the contractor must, at a minimum:

?    Have in place and certify compliance with an OSHA Process Safety Management Plan (PSM);
?    Make available to Helena

and EPA upon request, any documentation necessary to comply with the PSM;
?    Review, certify and comply with Helena?s emergency shut-down procedures for ammonia unloading, and emergency notification and evaluation procedures.

All of Helena?s contractors subject to this standard will be required to acknowledge and sign an Independent Contractor Certification Statement.  Helena will provide a copy of its Contingency Plan and Operating Procedures to its contractors for review and implementation.  A copy of the Helena RMP will be available for the independent contractor?s review at the Helena facility.  Helena personnel are responsible for providing notification to the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and Fire Department when its' contractor intends to operate the reactor.
 
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Helena Chemical Company?s Brunswick Facility is a non-responding facility. Helena has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at the Brunswick Facility.

CONCLUSION

The Risk Management Plan implemented by Helena Chemical Company at the Brunswick Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The RMP will be updated as the Brunswick Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Antelope County LEPC.

NOTE: Sections 4, 5, 6, and 7 of the standard RMP produced by EPA?s RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Brunswick Facility.
